questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of bright red blood in his stool for 5 days. He has had no pain during defecation and no abdominal pain. One year ago, he was diagnosed with cirrhosis after being admitted to the emergency department for upper gastrointestinal bleeding. He has since cut down on his drinking and consumes around 5 bottles of beer daily. Examination shows scleral icterus and mild ankle swelling. Palpation of the abdomen shows a fluid wave and shifting dullness. Anoscopy shows enlarged bluish vessels above the dentate line. Which of the following is the most likely source of bleeding in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Anorectal varices occur in patients with portal hypertension as a result of increased blood flow in the portosystemic anastomoses that connect the superior rectal vein with the inferior and middle rectal veins. The superior rectal vein receives blood from the region of the anal canal above the dentate line and drains into the inferior mesenteric vein (portal venous circulation). The superior rectal vein would be the source of bleeding in the case of lesions located above the dentate line, such as the anorectal varices seen in this patient. The inferior rectal veins, which receive blood from the region below the dentate line and drain into the internal pudendal veins (systemic venous circulation), would be the source of bleeding in the case of lesions located below the dentate line, such as external hemorrhoids.
Image Description:

Illustration depicting the dual lymphovascular supply of the anal canal

The anal valves form the pectinate line (seen as a longitudinal scalloped line), which divides the anal canal into upper and lower parts.

Arterial supply
Above the pectinate line:
- Superior rectal artery (a branch of the inferior mesenteric artery)
- Middle rectal artery (a branch of the internal iliac artery)
Below the pectinate line: inferior rectal artery (a branch of the internal pudendal artery)

Venous drainage (site of porto-systemic anastomosis)
Above the pectinate line:
- Superior rectal vein (drains into the inferior mesenteric vein, which drains into the portal vein)
- Middle rectal vein (drains into the internal iliac vein, a systemic vein)
Below the pectinate line: inferior rectal vein (drains into the internal pudendal vein, a systemic vein)

Lymphatic drainage
Above the pectinate line: into the internal iliac and inferior mesenteric lymph nodes
Below the pectinate line: into the superficial inguinal lymph nodes

B) INCORRECT:

Blood from the region of the anal canal below the pectinate line drains into the internal pudendal veins via its tributary. The anorectal varices in this patient are located above the dentate line, which is why a different vessel is the more likely source of bleeding. External hemorrhoids, which manifest with painful rectal bleeding, drain into the internal pudendal veins.

C) INCORRECT:

The inferior mesenteric artery does supply blood to the region of the anal canal above the dentate line via its branch, the superior rectal artery. However, the source of bleeding in this patient is an enlarged tortuous vein (varix), not an artery.

D) INCORRECT:

The inferior rectal veins receive blood from the region of the anal canal below the dentate line. The anorectal varices in this patient are located above the dentate line, which is why a different vessel is the more likely source of bleeding. The inferior rectal veins are the source of bleeding in external hemorrhoids, which manifest with painful rectal bleeding.

E) INCORRECT:

Blood from the region of the anal canal below the dentate line ultimately drains into the internal iliac veins. The anorectal varices in this patient are located above the dentate line, which is why a different vessel is the more likely source of bleeding. External hemorrhoids, which manifest with painful rectal bleeding, drain into the internal iliac veins.

F) INCORRECT:

The middle rectal artery does supply blood to the region of the anal canal above the dentate line. However, the source of bleeding in this patient is an enlarged tortuous vein (varix), not an artery.
questions.hint: The patient's anoscopy findings of anorectal varices in addition to his past medical history of liver cirrhosis and upper gastrointestinal bleeding suggest portal hypertension.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of bright red blood in her stools for 3 days. She has one bowel movement per day and no pain on defecation. She does not have a fever or abdominal pain. She was treated for a urinary tract infection with levofloxacin 3 months ago. Menses occur at regular intervals of 28–30 days and last 3–4 days. Her father died of colon cancer 4 years ago. Her only medication is an iron supplement. She is 162 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 101.2 kg (223 lbs); BMI is 38 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 89/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Rectal examination shows anal skin tags. Anoscopy shows multiple enlarged bluish veins above the dentate line at the 7 and 11 o'clock positions. During Valsalva maneuver, a rectal mass prolapses but spontaneously reduces when normal breathing is resumed. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Injection sclerotherapy is first-line therapy for grade III internal hemorrhoids, but it is usually used for grade I and grade II internal hemorrhoids that persist despite conservative therapy. Grade III internal hemorrhoids originate above the dentate line, prolapse when straining, and require manual reduction (i.e., do not reduce spontaneously). Because this patient has grade II internal hemorrhoids, a more conservative approach must first be considered.

B) INCORRECT:

Rubber band ligation is a procedure in which a rubber band is placed at the apex of an internal hemorrhoid, triggering an inflammatory response and fibrosis. This treatment is indicated for grade I and grade II internal hemorrhoids once conservative treatment has failed. In this patient's case, a more conservative approach should first be considered.

C) CORRECT:

Stool softeners (e.g., docusate and topical/suppository lidocaine if painful) are used for the conservative treatment of hemorrhoids. Further appropriate interventions include Sitz baths and lifestyle modifications (e.g., weight loss, exercise, high fiber diet, avoidance of fatty and spicy foods). Conservative therapy is the first-line management of external as well as grade I and grade II internal hemorrhoids.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical diltiazem may be used to relieve spasm of the anal sphincter that occurs in patients with painful thrombosed external hemorrhoids or following hemorrhoidectomy. It is also used as first-line management for chronic anal fissures. Patients with chronic anal fissures may present with rectal bleeding and an anal skin tag as seen in this patient. Although anal fissures may coexist with prolapsed hemorrhoids, they are always associated with pain during and after defecation. In addition, patients usually present with symptoms lasting more than 8–12 weeks.

E) INCORRECT:

Propranolol is used as secondary prophylaxis to prevent bleeding from rectal varices. It inhibits the β2-adrenoreceptors in the gastrointestinal tract causing splanchnic vasoconstriction, which in turn decreases the amount of blood in the portal veins and portal venous pressure. Rectal varices appear as tortuous dilated submucosal veins that extend beyond the levator ani and do not prolapse with pressure. Although varices may coexist with hemorrhoids in patients with cirrhosis, this patient is young and has no evidence of liver dysfunction. Therefore, propranolol would not have a role in the management of this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Infrared coagulation is a procedure in which focused infrared heat is used to coagulate and fibrose hemorrhoidal tissue. It is used as a first-line therapy for grade III internal hemorrhoids but can be used for grade I and grade II internal hemorrhoids that fail conservative management. Grade III internal hemorrhoids originate above the dentate line, prolapse when straining, and require manual reduction (i.e., do not reduce spontaneously). Because this patient has grade II internal hemorrhoids, a more conservative approach must first be considered.

G) INCORRECT:

Hemorrhoidectomy is used as a first-line treatment for grade IV internal hemorrhoids and patients with acutely thrombosed external hemorrhoids who present within 72 hours of symptom onset. Grade IV internal hemorrhoids originate above the dentate line but cannot be reduced (neither spontaneously nor manually), and external hemorrhoids originate below the dentate line and are extremely painful when thrombosed. Hemorrhoidectomy is indicated in grade II internal hemorrhoids as a last resort only. Because this patient has grade II internal hemorrhoids and has not yet failed initial therapy, a more conservative approach must first be considered.
questions.hint: Internal hemorrhoids originate above the dentate line and are generally painless. An internal hemorrhoid that protrudes outside the anus on straining but reduces spontaneously is a grade II internal hemorrhoid.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of severe perianal pain and bright red blood in his stool. Examination shows a bulging, red nodule at the rim of the anal opening. Which of the following arteries is the most likely source of blood to the mass found during examination?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The deep circumflex iliac artery is a branch of the external iliac artery that supplies the iliacus, iliac fossa, and deep abdominal wall of the inguinal region. This artery does not supply the anal canal.
Image Description:

Ventral view of important branches of the external iliac artery and femoral artery

After passing the inguinal ligament, the external iliac artery becomes the femoral artery. At this point, the profunda femoris artery emerges from the femoral artery and gives of the medial and lateral circumflex femoral artery.

B) CORRECT:

The internal pudendal artery gives rise to the inferior rectal artery, which supplies the part of the anal canal below the pectinate line, where external hemorrhoids develop. An external hemorrhoid is often painful because the region below the pectinate line arises from ectoderm and is innervated by the inferior rectal nerve, which transmits somatic sensations such as pain. Internal hemorrhoids, which arise above the pectinate line, are supplied by the superior rectal artery, a branch of the inferior mesenteric artery. Unlike external hemorrhoids, internal hemorrhoids are typically painless because the region of the anal canal above the pectinate line arises from endoderm and is innervated by the inferior hypogastric plexus, which carries visceral sensation only.
Image Description:

Illustration depicting the dual lymphovascular supply of the anal canal

The anal valves form the pectinate line (seen as a longitudinal scalloped line), which divides the anal canal into upper and lower parts.

Arterial supply
Above the pectinate line:
- Superior rectal artery (a branch of the inferior mesenteric artery)
- Middle rectal artery (a branch of the internal iliac artery)
Below the pectinate line: inferior rectal artery (a branch of the internal pudendal artery)

Venous drainage (site of porto-systemic anastomosis)
Above the pectinate line:
- Superior rectal vein (drains into the inferior mesenteric vein, which drains into the portal vein)
- Middle rectal vein (drains into the internal iliac vein, a systemic vein)
Below the pectinate line: inferior rectal vein (drains into the internal pudendal vein, a systemic vein)

Lymphatic drainage
Above the pectinate line: into the internal iliac and inferior mesenteric lymph nodes
Below the pectinate line: into the superficial inguinal lymph nodes

C) INCORRECT:

The median sacral artery is a branch of the abdominal aorta that supplies part of the lumbar vertebral column, the coccyx, and the sacrum. This artery does not supply the anal canal.

D) INCORRECT:

The inferior gluteal artery is a branch of the internal iliac artery that supplies the gluteus maximus, quadratus femoris, and piriformis muscles. Although external hemorrhoids are also supplied by a branch of the internal iliac artery, the inferior gluteal artery does not supply the anal canal.
Image Description:

Longitudinal section of the pelvis

E) INCORRECT:

The superior rectal artery supplies the anal canal above the pectinate line (where internal hemorrhoids develop). In contrast to external hemorrhoids, internal hemorrhoids are typically painless.
Image Description:

Internal hemorrhoids are located above the dentate line and are classified into the following grades based on the degree of prolapse:

Grade I: Hemorrhoids do not prolapse out of the anal verge.
Grade II: Hemorrhoids prolapse with straining, but reduce spontaneously.
Grade III: Hemorrhoids prolapse with straining and are only reducible manually.
Grade IV: Prolapse is irreducible.
questions.hint: Bright red blood in stool with a painful nodule at the rim of the anal opening suggests an external hemorrhoid.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman with a history of chronic constipation presents for her annual wellness visit with intermittent hematochezia and anal pruritus. She reports straining on the toilet to have a bowel movement at least twice per week. After bowel movements, she notes small amounts of bright-red blood, which drip into the toilet and are most noticeable when she wipes herself. She has not seen any blood mixed in with the stool and has no family history of colon cancer or inflammatory bowel disease.
Physical examination reveals a small, pale-blue mass at the anal verge. No other masses are apparent on rectal examination, and rectal tone is normal. Recent laboratory testing showed a hemoglobin concentration of 14.2 g/dL (reference range, 12.0–16.0).
What is the most appropriate next step in care for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients who do not respond to conservative therapies, such as fiber supplementation, or to other medical treatments for constipation have several other treatment options available, including rubber band ligation for internal hemorrhoids.

B) INCORRECT:

Colonoscopy is not required as part of initial management in patients younger than age 40 who have classic hemorrhoid symptoms, a visible hemorrhoid on examination or anoscopy, and no alarm features (such as a family history of colon cancer, a large amount of bleeding, abdominal pain, diarrhea, weight loss, anemia, or systemic symptoms). However, if rectal bleeding does not resolve with treatment of the hemorrhoid, then endoscopic evaluation may be considered.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients who do not respond to conservative therapies, such as fiber supplementation, or to other medical treatments for constipation have several other treatment options available, including sclerotherapy, which involves injection of a sclerosant. Sclerotherapy is less effective than rubber band ligation, but it is also less likely to cause bleeding than ligation and can therefore be used in patients who take anticoagulant or antiplatelet medications.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients who do not respond to conservative therapies, such as fiber supplementation, or to other medical treatments for constipation have several other treatment options available, including hemorrhoidectomy for external hemorrhoids.

E) CORRECT:

This patient presents with an external hemorrhoid and symptoms of intermittent bleeding and anal itching. Hemorrhoids are often exacerbated by constipation and straining. Thus, affected patients are advised to reduce straining, ensure adequate water intake, and start fiber supplementation if symptomatic. Fiber supplementation has been shown to reduce bleeding in patients with symptomatic hemorrhoids and may improve other symptoms, such as itching, as well.

Patients who do not respond to conservative therapies, such as fiber supplementation, or to other medical treatments for constipation have several other treatment options available, including:

• Hemorrhoidectomy for external hemorrhoids
• Rubber band ligation for internal hemorrhoids
• Sclerotherapy, which involves injection of a sclerosant

Sclerotherapy is less effective than rubber band ligation, but it is also less likely to cause bleeding than ligation and can therefore be used in patients who take anticoagulant or antiplatelet medications.

Key learning point: The first step in managing a simple symptomatic hemorrhoid is fiber supplementation.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to the office with a 3-day history of painful defecation. He has had intermittent constipation and itching around the anus after being started on an opioid for a knee injury 5 months ago. He has no rectal bleeding, fever, or changes in bowel habits. He works as a personal trainer in a gym. Vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, his abdomen is soft. A tender, purplish 1-cm mass is noted at the anal verge. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rectal prolapse manifests with a mass that is sometimes visible on examination and often causes anal pruritus. Also, chronic constipation is a risk factor for developing rectal prolapse. However, rectal prolapse typically protrudes from the anus and manifests as a painless mass with rectal mucosal folds, and this patient presents with a purplish, painful mass at the anal verge. Furthermore, fecal incontinence is a common clinical feature of rectal prolapse but is not seen here.
Image Description:

All layers of the rectal wall protrude through the anus (∼ 10 cm in this patient).

B) INCORRECT:

Anal fissures typically cause acute-onset painful defecation and anal pruritus, and are often a result of chronic constipation. However, anal fissures usually manifest as a superficial tear in the anoderm in the posterior midline rather than a purplish mass at the anal verge.
Image Description:

Gentle retraction of the buttocks (not shown) reveals a tear in the anoderm (arrow). The absence of chronic features, such as a sentinel skin tag, suggests this is likely an acute anal fissure.

C) CORRECT:

Thrombosed external hemorrhoids are caused by blood stasis within an external hemorrhoid leading to thrombus formation. Common causes include excessive straining from chronic constipation or heavy lifting. Thrombosed hemorrhoids typically have an acute onset, manifesting with a severely painful, palpable, tender, dark red to purplish nodule at the anal verge or just within the anal canal. Diagnosis is clinical. Pain usually improves after the first 2–3 days as the thrombus is gradually absorbed. Surgical excision of a thrombosed hemorrhoid is recommended for patients who present within 3–4 days of symptom onset, as excision leads to faster pain relief, lower recurrence rates, and longer remission periods than conservative management. For patients presenting > 4 days after symptom onset, conservative treatment with analgesia and topical anti-inflammatory agents is preferred.
Image Description:

Perianal region with patient in left lateral position

A purplish bulging nodule is visible in the right lateral position of the anal verge, which is the characteristic appearance of a thrombosed external hemorrhoid. Additionally, an anal skin tag is visible in the posterior aspect of the anal verge.

D) INCORRECT:

Anal carcinomas may present with pruritus and a mass at the anal verge, but they are typically characterized by a firm, irregular, or ulcerated lesion rather than a tender, purplish mass. Acute-onset pain is uncommon, as anal carcinoma generally develops gradually. The most prominent initial symptom is rectal bleeding, often accompanied by systemic symptoms such as weight loss.
Image Description:

A friable, exophytic mass is visible at the anal orifice.

These features suggest an anal cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

Perianal abscesses manifest with pain and pruritus on defecation. However, this patient presents with a purplish mass on the anal verge and does not have other typical symptoms of perianal abscess, such as fluctuance, induration, purulent discharge, and erythematous swelling.
Image Description:

There is a prominent area of erythema and swelling on the left buttock and perianal region.

This is the typical appearance of an anal abscess.
questions.hint: Constipation is a common cause of this patient's condition, which may manifest with intermittent scant hematochezia.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a history of chronic constipation presents for her annual wellness visit with intermittent hematochezia and anal pruritus. She reports straining on the toilet to have a bowel movement at least twice per week. After bowel movements, she notes small amounts of bright red blood, which drip into the toilet and are most noticeable when she wipes herself. She has not seen any blood mixed in with the stool and has no family history of colon cancer or inflammatory bowel disease. Physical examination reveals a small, pale-blue mass at the anal verge. No other masses are apparent on rectal examination, and rectal tone is normal. Recent laboratory testing showed a hemoglobin concentration of 14.2 g/dL. What is the most appropriate next step in care for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients who do not respond to conservative therapies, such as fiber supplementation, or to other medical treatments for constipation have several other treatment options available, including rubber band ligation for internal hemorrhoids.

B) INCORRECT:

Colonoscopy is not required as part of initial management in patients younger than age 40 who have classic hemorrhoid symptoms, a visible hemorrhoid on examination or anoscopy, and no alarm features (such as a family history of colon cancer, a large amount of bleeding, abdominal pain, diarrhea, weight loss, anemia, or systemic symptoms). However, if rectal bleeding does not resolve with treatment of the hemorrhoid, then endoscopic evaluation may be considered.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients who do not respond to conservative therapies, such as fiber supplementation, or to other medical treatments for constipation have several other treatment options available, including sclerotherapy, which involves injection of a sclerosant. Sclerotherapy is less effective than rubber band ligation, but it is also less likely to cause bleeding than ligation and can therefore be used in patients who take anticoagulant or antiplatelet medications.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients who do not respond to conservative therapies, such as fiber supplementation, or to other medical treatments for constipation have several other treatment options available, including hemorrhoidectomy for external hemorrhoids.

E) CORRECT:

This patient presents with an external hemorrhoid and symptoms of intermittent bleeding and anal itching. Hemorrhoids are often exacerbated by constipation and straining. Thus, affected patients are advised to reduce straining, ensure adequate water intake, and start fiber supplementation if symptomatic. Fiber supplementation has been shown to reduce bleeding in patients with symptomatic hemorrhoids and may improve other symptoms, such as itching, as well.

Patients who do not respond to conservative therapies, such as fiber supplementation, or to other medical treatments for constipation have several other treatment options available, including:

• Hemorrhoidectomy for external hemorrhoids
• Rubber band ligation for internal hemorrhoids
• Sclerotherapy, which involves injection of a sclerosant

Sclerotherapy is less effective than rubber band ligation, but it is also less likely to cause bleeding than ligation and can therefore be used in patients who take anticoagulant or antiplatelet medications.

Key learning point: The first step in managing a simple symptomatic hemorrhoid is fiber supplementation.
questions.hint: Bright red blood in stool with a painful mass at the rim of the anal opening suggests an external hemorrhoid.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man presents with sudden onset of severe anal pain after straining during a bowel movement. He reports that the pain worsens while sitting and improves with warm sitz baths. He has tried over-the-counter hemorrhoid creams with minimal relief. He denies fever, chills, or other systemic symptoms. Examination reveals a small, bluish, tender swelling at the anal verge, with a discrete lesion and no surrounding erythema or purulent discharge. Laboratory evaluations, including a complete blood count, are within normal limits.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anal fissures typically present as linear tears in the anoderm, often in the posterior midline, and may cause bright red blood on stool or toilet paper. The described bluish, tender swelling at the anal verge is inconsistent with the mucosal tear seen in anal fissures, indicating a vascular event instead.

B) INCORRECT:

Perianal abscesses usually present with diffuse erythema, fluctuance, or purulent discharge, indicating an infectious process. The absence of erythema, discharge, and systemic signs such as fever, along with the presence of a bluish, tender lesion, suggests a vascular event rather than an abscess.

C) CORRECT:

Thrombosed external hemorrhoids manifest with sudden, severe anal pain following straining during a bowel movement. The pain results from thrombosis in the vascular tissue distal to the dentate line, where somatic innervation makes the area highly sensitive. The bluish, tender swelling at the anal verge reflects blood extravasation beneath the skin. The absence of systemic symptoms, such as fever, supports a local vascular event rather than an infection. Warm sitz baths alleviate symptoms by promoting venous drainage. This clinical presentation aligns with the pathophysiology of thrombosed external hemorrhoids.

Key learning point: A painful, tender swelling near the anal verge without systemic signs of infection is most consistent with a perianal hematoma, also known as a thrombosed external hemorrhoid.
Image Description:

Perianal region with patient in lithotomy position

A pink-purple nodule with hemorrhagic blisters on the surface is visible in the right lateral position of the anal verge.

This is the characteristic appearance of a thrombosed hemorrhoid, which is an acutely painful complication of external hemorrhoids.

D) INCORRECT:

Pilonidal cysts typically occur in the sacrococcygeal region and present as chronic lesions with possible infection signs like erythema and discharge. The sudden onset of pain, bluish swelling at the anal verge, and lack of systemic or localized inflammatory signs are more indicative of a vascular event than a pilonidal cyst.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presents with 3 weeks of bright red blood coating his stool during bowel movements. He denies abdominal pain but occasionally experiences perianal discomfort and pruritus. He has not noticed any significant changes in bowel habits. He is otherwise healthy with no known chronic medical conditions. On inspection, there are no visible external lesions in the perianal area. Laboratory evaluation, including hemoglobin, is within normal limits.
Which of the following is the most likely cause of his bleeding?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diverticular disease typically presents with sudden, painless, and sometimes brisk bleeding, often in older individuals. The patient's age, perianal discomfort, and pruritus suggest a process near the anorectal region, not the colon, where diverticula are located.

B) CORRECT:

Internal hemorrhoids are dilated vascular cushions located above the dentate line, leading to minimal pain despite bleeding due to visceral innervation. Bright red blood coating the stool suggests a lower gastrointestinal source, typical of internal hemorrhoids. The absence of severe pain and normal hemoglobin levels indicate slight bleeding consistent with a benign anorectal condition. Anoscopy can confirm the diagnosis by visualizing engorged vascular structures.

Key learning point: Painless fresh bleeding post defecation is most commonly associated with hemorrhoids, which are swollen blood vessels in the rectal area.

C) INCORRECT:

Rectal carcinoma often presents with systemic symptoms, changes in bowel habits, and is more common in older patients. The patient's bright red blood coating the stool, normal hemoglobin, and lack of systemic symptoms suggest a benign anorectal lesion rather than carcinoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Anal fissures cause severe, sharp pain during defecation and are visible as linear tears in the anoderm. The absence of intense pain and visible fissures, along with the description of bright red blood coating the stool, makes anal fissures unlikely.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 3-day history of painful defecation. He reports intermittent constipation and itching around the anus since starting an opioid for a knee injury 5 months ago. He denies rectal bleeding, fever, or changes in bowel habits. He works as a personal trainer at a gym. Vital signs are normal. On examination, his abdomen is soft. A tender, purplish 1-cm mass is present at the anal verge. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Thrombosed external hemorrhoids are caused by blood stasis within an external hemorrhoid leading to thrombus formation. Common causes include excessive straining from chronic constipation or heavy lifting. Thrombosed hemorrhoids typically have an acute onset, manifesting with a severely painful, palpable, tender, dark red to purplish nodule at the anal verge or just within the anal canal. Diagnosis is clinical. Pain usually improves after the first 2–3 days as the thrombus is gradually absorbed. Surgical excision of a thrombosed hemorrhoid is recommended for patients who present within 3–4 days of symptom onset, as excision leads to faster pain relief, lower recurrence rates, and longer remission periods than conservative management. For patients presenting > 4 days after symptom onset, conservative treatment with analgesia and topical anti-inflammatory agents is preferred.

Key learning point: A thrombosed external hemorrhoid presents as an acutely painful, tender, purplish nodule at the anal verge, often triggered by straining or constipation.
Image Description:

Perianal region with patient in left lateral position

A purplish bulging nodule is visible in the right lateral position of the anal verge, which is the characteristic appearance of a thrombosed external hemorrhoid. Additionally, an anal skin tag is visible in the posterior aspect of the anal verge.

B) INCORRECT:

Anal fissures typically cause acute-onset painful defecation and anal pruritus, and are often a result of chronic constipation. However, anal fissures usually manifest as a superficial tear in the anoderm in the posterior midline rather than a purplish mass at the anal verge.

C) INCORRECT:

Anal carcinomas may present with pruritus and a mass at the anal verge, but they are typically characterized by a firm, irregular, or ulcerated lesion rather than a tender, purplish mass. Acute-onset pain is uncommon, as anal carcinoma generally develops gradually. The most prominent initial symptom is rectal bleeding, often accompanied by systemic symptoms such as weight loss.

D) INCORRECT:

Rectal prolapse manifests with a mass that is sometimes visible on examination and often causes anal pruritus. Also, chronic constipation is a risk factor for developing rectal prolapse. However, rectal prolapse typically protrudes from the anus and manifests as a painless mass with rectal mucosal folds, and this patient presents with a purplish, painful mass at the anal verge. Furthermore, fecal incontinence is a common clinical feature of rectal prolapse but is not seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Perianal abscesses manifest with pain and pruritus on defecation. However, this patient presents with a purplish mass on the anal verge and does not have other typical symptoms of perianal abscess, such as fluctuance, induration, purulent discharge, and erythematous swelling.
questions.hint: Constipation is a common cause of this patient's condition, which may manifest with intermittent scant hematochezia.

questions.text: A 42-year-old construction worker presents with a 3-week history of intermittent bright red blood on toilet paper and mild perianal itching. He denies pain during defecation. Physical examination shows no obvious external masses at rest, but straining shows a small protrusion that immediately retracts. Digital rectal examination shows no masses or obvious abnormalities. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Initiating topical corticosteroid therapy without a proper diagnosis is inappropriate. Treatment decisions should be based on proper diagnostic evaluation.

B) INCORRECT:

Colonoscopy is not the initial diagnostic test for suspected hemorrhoids in a patient aged < 45 years without risk factors for colorectal cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

Surgical referral for suspected hemorrhoids is inappropriate without proper diagnosis and grading. This patient's clinical presentation suggests early-stage internal hemorrhoids, which typically respond well to conservative management. Surgical intervention is generally reserved for grade III–IV hemorrhoids that are refractory to medical management.

D) INCORRECT:

Flexible sigmoidoscopy is indicated for suspected hemorrhoids if anoscopy provides inadequate visualization or clinical uncertainty persists after initial evaluation.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- Anoscopy is required in all patients with suspected hemorrhoids to directly visualize the anal canal and distal rectum. This patient's presentation suggests internal hemorrhoids, but anoscopy is essential to differentiate internal from external hemorrhoids, determine the grade, and exclude other anorectal pathology such as anal fissures, polyps, or carcinoma. Internal hemorrhoids are often not palpable on digital rectal examination and may only be visible with anoscopy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old construction worker presents with a 4-day history of severe, constant perianal pain and a tender mass. He notes that the pain began suddenly after straining during defecation and has worsened despite over-the-counter pain medications. Physical examination shows a tense, dark purple, 1.5-cm nodule at the anal verge that is exquisitely tender to palpation. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Incision and drainage of the mass
Conservative management with sitz baths and topical analgesics
Surgical excision of the thrombosed hemorrhoid

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Simple incision and drainage is not the appropriate surgical technique for a thrombosed external hemorrhoid.

B) INCORRECT:

Antibiotics are not routinely indicated for uncomplicated thrombosed external hemorrhoids, unless there are signs of secondary infection such as cellulitis, fever, or purulent discharge. The condition is primarily a vascular thrombosis, not an infectious process.

C) INCORRECT:

Rubber band ligation is used for grade I–III internal hemorrhoids that are unresponsive to conservative treatment. This procedure is not appropriate for external hemorrhoids, particularly thrombosed ones, as the somatic innervation below the dentate line causes severe pain.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Conservative management of thrombosed external hemorrhoids is indicated for patients who present after 3–4 days of symptom onset, as the risk of procedural pain outweighs the benefit since thrombosed hemorrhoids typically resolve spontaneously over 7–10 days. Treatment includes sitz baths, topical analgesics, and stool softeners.

E) INCORRECT:

Surgical excision is only indicated for thrombosed external hemorrhoids if patients present within 3–4 days of symptom onset with severe pain. After this timeframe, conservative management is preferred because the natural resolution process has begun, and surgical intervention carries more risk than benefit.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe perianal pain that began 36 hours ago while straining during defecation. He describes the pain as throbbing and constant, rating it 8/10, with worsening during sitting and bowel movements. Physical examination shows a 1.5-cm tender, dark purple nodule at the 7 o'clock position of the anal verge. The patient has a history of chronic constipation and takes no medications. Vital signs are normal. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Sitz baths and topical hydrocortisone cream
Incision and drainage of the lesion
Surgical excision of the thrombosed hemorrhoid

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical nitroglycerin ointment helps reduce anal sphincter spasm but is not the primary treatment for thrombosed external hemorrhoids. This ointment serves as an adjunctive therapy for symptom relief but does not address the thrombus itself.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral analgesics and stool softeners are supportive measures but do not optimally address the underlying thrombosed hemorrhoid in a patient presenting within the therapeutic window for surgical intervention. This approach is more appropriate for later presentations or as adjunctive therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Sitz baths and topical corticosteroids are components of conservative management but are not optimal for a patient presenting early with severe symptoms. Conservative management is more appropriate for patients presenting after 3–4 days of symptom onset or those with mild to moderate symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Incision and drainage is not the recommended surgical technique for thrombosed external hemorrhoids. This approach is more likely to result in inadequate clot removal, resulting in higher recurrence rates and the formation of skin tags.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- Surgical excision is the most appropriate management for this patient presenting within 3–4 days of symptom onset with severe pain from a thrombosed external hemorrhoid. It provides faster pain relief, lower recurrence rates, and longer remission periods compared to conservative management. The timeline of 36 hours since onset and the severe intensity of pain make this patient an ideal candidate for surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents to the urgent care clinic with a 24-hour history of severe, constant perianal pain. He reports noticing a painful lump near his anus after a heavy weightlifting session yesterday. He denies any fever, chills, or significant rectal bleeding, although he noted a small streak of blood on the toilet paper this morning. He has a history of occasional constipation. Vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the mass is shown. The mass is firm, exquisitely tender, and not fluctuant. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An anal fissure causes severe pain, but the pain is classically described as sharp and tearing during defecation, followed by a deep, burning ache. The physical finding is a linear tear or ulcer in the anoderm, most commonly in the posterior midline, not a discrete, ovoid mass. While there can be a sentinel skin tag with chronic fissures, the acute presentation is not a thrombosed-appearing lump.

B) INCORRECT:

A perianal abscess presents as a painful, tender mass. However, an abscess is typically erythematous, warm, and fluctuant due to the collection of pus, whereas this patient's mass is purplish and firm.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for a thrombosed external hemorrhoid. These occur when a blood clot forms in a hemorrhoidal vessel located distal to the dentate line. The acute onset of severe, constant pain is characteristic because this area is covered by somatic sensory nerves. The physical exam finding of a tender, tense, purplish nodule at the anal verge is characteristic. Activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure, like heavy lifting or straining during defecation, are common precipitants. Treatment for symptoms presenting within 72 hours often involves incision and evacuation of the thrombus, which provides immediate pain relief.

D) INCORRECT:

An anorectal fistula is an abnormal tract connecting the anal canal to the perianal skin. It typically presents with intermittent or persistent purulent drainage from an external opening, along with associated itching or discomfort. It does not manifest as an acute, exquisitely tender, purplish ovoid mass.

E) INCORRECT:

A prolapsed internal hemorrhoid is a palpable mass at the anus that originates proximal to the dentate line. While it can be associated with straining and bleeding, it is typically painless due to visceral innervation. Pain only develops if the hemorrhoid becomes strangulated, leading to edema and possible thrombosis, but the primary presentation is usually a reducible or non-reducible pinkish mass rather than an exquisitely tender, purplish, firm nodule.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents to the urgent care clinic with a 24-hour history of severe, constant anal pain. He reports noticing a painful lump near his anus this morning. He has a history of chronic constipation but is otherwise healthy. He hasn't had any fever or significant rectal bleeding. Physical examination shows a 1.5-cm, tense, tender, purplish nodule at the anal verge in the 5 o'clock position. The remainder of the rectal examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate intervention?

choices.text: Rubber band ligation of the lesion
Sitz baths, stool softeners, and analgesics

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sclerotherapy involves injecting a chemical agent to cause fibrosis and is a treatment option for bleeding, low-grade internal hemorrhoids. It is not indicated for external hemorrhoids, and it would not resolve the acute thrombus or provide the rapid pain relief needed in this clinical scenario. The lesion's location at the anal verge makes this an inappropriate choice.

B) INCORRECT:

Rubber band ligation is an effective office-based procedure for symptomatic internal hemorrhoids, which originate above the dentate line and are covered by insensitive mucosa. This patient's lesion is at the anal verge, which indicates it is an external hemorrhoid covered by somatically innervated skin. Applying a rubber band to this highly sensitive area would cause excruciating pain and is contraindicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Conservative management with sitz baths, stool softeners, and analgesics is a reasonable approach for hemorrhoids. However, for an acutely thrombosed external hemorrhoid with severe pain that presents within 72-96 hours, this approach offers slow and often inadequate relief. It is typically reserved for patients who present after 72-96 hours, when the acute pain has begun to resolve spontaneously, or for those with less severe symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

A formal surgical hemorrhoidectomy is an operating room procedure reserved for extensive, refractory, or complicated hemorrhoidal disease, such as large grade III or IV internal hemorrhoids. It is an overly aggressive intervention for a single, localized thrombosed external hemorrhoid, which can be effectively managed with a much simpler office-based excision. The morbidity of a formal hemorrhoidectomy is not justified in this case.

E) CORRECT:

For patients who present within 72-96 hours of symptom onset, excision of the hemorrhoid under local anesthesia is the treatment of choice. This procedure involves making an elliptical incision over the thrombus, evacuating the clot, and excising the overlying redundant skin. It provides immediate pain relief and has a lower recurrence rate compared with simple incision and drainage. Chronic constipation is a common predisposing factor due to straining.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of a painful, purplish nodule at the anal verge is characteristic of an acutely thrombosed external hemorrhoid. The optimal treatment for this condition depends on the timing of symptom onset and the severity of pain.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man presents to the clinic three months after a surgical procedure for symptomatic internal hemorrhoids. He reports progressively worsening pain with defecation, difficulty passing stool, and narrower stools. He often strains. Inspection reveals no external lesions. On attempted digital rectal examination, he experiences severe pain, and the anal canal appears extremely tight, preventing complete insertion of the examiner’s finger.
Which of the following best explains these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rectal strictures result from inflammation or surgical interventions involving the rectum, leading to luminal narrowing. However, the tight anal canal preventing full finger insertion suggests a localized process at the anal verge, consistent with anal stenosis, rather than a rectal stricture.

B) CORRECT:

Anal stenosis manifests as a narrowing of the anal canal, often due to scar formation following surgical procedures like hemorrhoidectomy. This patient’s symptoms of progressively worsening pain with defecation, difficulty passing stool, and narrow stools, along with the finding of a tight anal canal on examination, suggest reduced anal canal distensibility. These features indicate mechanical obstruction and reduced compliance due to fibrosis, consistent with anal stenosis.

Key learning point: Anal stenosis can occur as a complication of hemorrhoidectomy and may present with severe pain and difficulty passing stool, potentially preventing digital rectal examination.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic anal fissures cause severe pain on defecation and sphincter spasms, but they do not lead to circumferential narrowing of the anal canal. The absence of a linear ulceration or sentinel skin tag and the presence of a tight anal canal suggest a structural change inconsistent with a chronic fissure.

D) INCORRECT:

Recurrent hemorrhoids typically present with intermittent bleeding, prolapse, or discomfort, not with a mechanically narrowed anal canal. The symptoms of narrow stools, frequent straining, and a tight anal canal are more indicative of anal stenosis due to postoperative fibrosis rather than recurrent hemorrhoids.
